WRITING.TITLE: Having a small crisis
WRITING.TEXT: Okay so maybe crisis is the wrong word BUT it's something that's been on my mind for a long time and keeps getting worse. So I'm F18 and in uni, I feel so incredibly inexperienced and out of place, I've never been in love with someone and only really had base level attraction to people, I've never even kissed anyone. I know that there is too much pressure on people to have certain things done by a certain age but that doesn't erase the fact that I feel so behind. I don't know what to do, while to my knowledge I've never had anyone seriously attracted to me anytime the opportunity arises (e.g. at a club or whatever) I go into self sabotage mode and shut myself down. I don't know what to do, I don't want my first times to be a big deal at all but I feel like the older I get the bigger of a deal it seems? Idk dudes

That's whack, I'm from Australia and (correct me fellow aussies if I'm wrong) but you're restricted from donating blood not if you identify as gay but if you've had "risky" sexual intercourse including unprotected sex altogether. All of that is to prevent risk of AIDs transfers

I'm sure they do but idk about everywhere else but blood donation is primarily run by non for profits like the red cross here, the actual collection of the blood takes a lot of time and resources not to mention the testing and distribution. While they obviously get paid for the blood, having people who participate in at risk sexual intercourse abstain from giving blood in the first place would prevent them from gathering the blood and using all those resources and then having to dispose of it because it's contaminated, which it would be at a much higher rate for those who participate in such activity. This is all what I'm assuming fyi I'm not well versed in the research and stuff. Believe me, blood banks are desperate as hell to get people's blood, the supply and demand is so out of balance, they would not write off a whole group of people if it wasn't absolutely necessary.
Well that's why the rule is there, if you have any form of unprotected sex, you're not eligible.
It's people's health they're not going to take any risks

I personally think the deferal period should be lowered to something like 6 months, however the facts are that specifically gay men are at a higher risk of contracting HIV and that even the most up to date tests are still not perfect, so they are not going to take any risks when handling something as important and risky as blood transfusions

They're literally trying to protect people's lives, especially because the people receiving these donations are already ill, they're not going to risk that because it's upsetting to some people. I understand that this sucks for a lot of people, I really really do, but the reality is experts and professionals have undertaken extensive research and found that it is a necessary step to protect people's health. It's not about prejudice it's about minimizing risk factors as much as possible.
Low key great
surely not lmao, sources I'm intrigued???

WRITING.TITLE: Dear Extinction Rebellion...
WRITING.TEXT: I'm sure I'll be down-voted into the depths of hell for this post but never the less (or just no one will give af oh well): As a university student and young person who is concerned for the future health of our planet I am just as concerned and empathetic to the cause of climate change as many of you. Our time on this planet is precious and it is vital that we leave it in a better condition then how we found it. The last three generations in particular have been instrumental in the change and destruction of many of our earth's precious resources as a result of things like globalisation and the rise of massive corporation. However, punishing the people going about their daily lives as you have been doing in Melbourne is not the way to go about making people listen to you. Every time you pull things like this you diminish your credibility and turn away those who can make a difference- the general people. Not only is this a poor political strategy but it takes away the work that those who are *constructively* trying to make change do. While each individual impacts our planet and has the ability to make change it is ultimately out of the general populations hands until it comes to election time- by which if you keep going at the rate you do, you will have turned away the people who matter. Rally big business to take social and environmental responsibility, petition the government and use the forums in place to make your voice heard, hell protest outside of parliament for all I care, you have every reason to exercise your right to democracy and free speech but ruining the days and work of those within the local community is wrong for a million reasons it is not constructive to your cause or the planet. Sincerely, A concerned student TLDR: Extinction rebellion get your head out of your ass you're ruining the fight for climate justice by being destructive and fighting the wrong demographics
As opposed to "we're yelling at you so you must listen to us" ?

Personally, I think it boosts sympathy to the Liberal party they will go "Oh No look at all these radical greenies disrupting your lives blah blah blah they dont care about you OR the planet they just want attention". I think it's really important not to ignore the general public, it's (partially) someone like Trump won his election, he took advantage of what the left overlooked

Look I think protests are a fundamental part of democracy they show that the people want change- which I would argue things like the School Strike 4 Climate successfully showed, it was a big movement and a great way to show the people want change. It's really great that in the case of Littleproud he was able to gain a new perspective. But what they are doing today/ yesterday is only pissing off people to the point where they won't listen out of spite
Yeah this is what I mean, and it genuinely is saddening to here that, I am sorry that you feel this way

Yeah see I totally respect that point of view but I just think given the state of Australian politics at the moment it's the wrong angle to take, and who knows I could be proven completely wrong in a month or 5 years but yeah it's just my point of view
